page.title: 4.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn about functions. You will examine examples of functions and their representations in context.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain when a relationship between two quantities is a function.
  • Identify independent and dependent variables in a function, and use words and graphs to represent the function.
  • Explain what descriptions and graphs of functions tell us about situations.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.1.1: Contrasting Two Relationships by Reasoning
  • 4.1.2: Reasoning Graphically About the Relationship between the Two Quantities
  • 4.1.2: Self Check
  • 4.1.3: Examining Relations and Functions
  • 4.1.3: Self Check
  • 4.1.4: Describing Functional Relationships
  • 4.1.4: Self Check
  • 4.1.5: Modeling Relationships between Two Variables

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.1.6: Practice
  • 4.1.7: Lesson Summary

answer.answer_text: Next

page.title: 4.1.1: Contrasting Two Relationships by Reasoning
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity



A customer at a bagel shop is buying 13 bagels. The store worker says, “That would be $16.25.”

Jaime, Pedro, and Hannah, who are in the shop, all think it is a mistake.

  • Jaime says, “Shouldn’t the total be $13.25?”
  • Pedro says, “I think it should be $13.00.”
  • Hannah says, “No, I think it should be $11.25.”

Explain how the store worker, Jaime, Pedro, and Hannah could all be right.

Your teacher will give you instructions for completing the table.

number
of bagels

in respective text entry area

2

4

D. _____

6

F. _____

G. _____

9

10

J. _____

11

K. _____

12

L. _____

13

M. _____



Number of bagels 1 = A._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

1.25



Number of bagels 2 = B._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

2.50



Number of bagels 3 = C._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

3.75



Number of bagels 3 = D._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

5.00



Number of bagels 3 = E._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

6.25



Number of bagels 3 = F._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

6.00



Number of bagels 3 = G._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

7.25



Number of bagels 3 = H._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

8.50



Number of bagels 3 = I._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

8.00



Number of bagels 3 = J._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

9.25



Number of bagels 3 = K._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

10.50



Number of bagels 3 = L._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

10.00



Number of bagels 3 = M._____

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

11.25


In this activity, because there was only one best price for a particular number of bagels, the best price is a function of the number of bagels bought. A function assigns one output to each input.

page.title: 4.1.2: Reasoning Graphically About the Relationship between the Two Quantities
page.contents:
Activity

Three days in a row, a dog owner tied his dog’s 5-foot-long leash to a post outside a store while he ran into the store to get a drink. Each time, the owner returned within minutes.

The dog’s movement each day is described here.

  • Day 1: The dog walked around the entire time while waiting for its owner.
  • Day 2: The dog walked around for the first minute and then laid down until its owner returned.
  • Day 3: The dog tried to follow its owner into the store but was stopped by the leash. Then, it started walking around the post in one direction. It kept walking until its leash was completely wound up around the post. The dog stayed there until its owner returned.
  • Each day, the dog was 1.5 feet away from the post when the owner left.
  • Each day, 60 seconds after the owner left, the dog was 4 feet from the post.

Your teacher will assign one of the days for you to analyze. You will sketch a graph that could represent the dog’s distance from the post, in feet, as a function of time, in seconds, since the owner left.

Then, meet with someone in your group who had Day 2’s movement and someone who had Day 3’s movement. Work together to explain your graphs and make changes where needed before checking your work. Be sure to sketch each other’s graphs.

Day _____



Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Sketch the graph for Day 1.

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:


Sketch the graph for Day 2.

Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:


Sketch the graph for Day 3.

Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:


Extending Your Thinking

From the graph, is it possible to tell how many times the dog changed directions while walking around? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No. The graph only gives the distance from the post. The dog could change from moving clockwise around the post to moving counterclockwise around the post. These changes could not be seen on the graph.

answer.answer_text: Previous

page.title: 4.1.2: Self Check
page.contents: The graph below shows a person’s elevation for a period of 10 minutes. Which statement below is true based on the graph?

answer.answer_text: The person sped up in the first 3 minutes.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The graph is looking at time and elevation, not speed. The answer is that the person was hiking up a hill for the first 3 minutes.

answer.answer_text: The person slowed down for the second half of the hike.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The graph is looking at time and elevation, not speed. The answer is that the person was hiking up a hill for the first 3 minutes.

answer.answer_text: During the first 3 minutes, the person was hiking up a hill.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: As time passed during the first 3 minutes, the person’s elevation increased.

answer.answer_text: The person never stopped climbing.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The elevation stayed the same from 3 to 4 minutes and about 5 to 6 minutes, so that is where they stopped climbing. The answer is that the person was hiking up a hill for the first 3 minutes.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Representing Everyday Situations with Graphs

Graphing functions to represent everyday situations can be useful to provide a visual for what is happening in a situation.

Example 1:

The graph shows the distance \(y\), in miles, for the time of each of Mia’s runs \(x\), in minutes.


Notice that at 0 minutes, Mia has run 0 miles. At 30 minutes, Mia has run 3 miles. At 180 minutes, Mia has run 18 miles.

Try It: Represent Everyday Situations with Graphs

Sky spends 5 hours at the library. She is on their internet for an hour. Then she takes an hour break to read a book. She then is back online for 2 hours before her friend comes to talk for an hour. She spends her last hour at the library on the internet.


Draw this situation where the time spent on the internet, in hours, is a function of time spent at the library, in hours.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to represent this situation in a graph:

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.1.3: Examining Relations and Functions
page.contents:
Activity

A relation is any set of ordered pairs, \((x,y)\).

A function is a special type of relation that maps every input, \(x\), to exactly one output, \(y\).

Tell if each relation is a function and explain.


\(x\)

\(y\)

–3

3

–2

2

–1

1

0

0

1

1

2

2

3

3


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes, this is a function because every input goes to exactly one output.






Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This relation is not a function. Raul and Jenny have 2 emails, so twice there are inputs that go to two outputs.






Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

This is not a function because each input goes to multiple outputs.




  1. {\((−3,27),(−2,8),(−1,1),(0,0),(1,1),(2,8),(3,27)\)}

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Each input, \(x\)-value, is matched with only one output, \(y\)-value. So this relation is a function.




  1. {\((9,−3),(4,−2),(1,−1),(0,0),(1,1),(4,2),(9,3)\)}

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The input (\(x\)-value), 9, is matched with two outputs (\(y\)-values), both 3 and –3. So this relation is not a function.

answer.answer_text: Previous
Next

page.title: 4.1.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Consider the two relations below. Which statement is true about both relations?

  1. {\((−3,−6),(−2,−4),(−1,−2),(0,0),(1,2),(2,4),(3,6)\)}
  2. {\((8,−4),(4,−2),(2,−1),(0,0),(2,1),(4,2),(8,4)\)}

answer.answer_text: Both relations are functions.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: In relation b, the input, 4, is shared with 2 outputs. The answer is that relation a is a function, but relation b is not.

answer.answer_text: Relation a is a function, but relation b is not a function.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: In relation a, every input goes to exactly one output, but in relation b, the input value 4 goes to both –2 and 2.

answer.answer_text: Relation b is a function, but relation a is not a function.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Relation b is not a function because the input value 4 goes to both 2 and –2. Relation a has every input value going to exactly one output value. The answer is that relation a is a function, but relation b is not.

answer.answer_text: Neither relation is a function.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Relation a is a function since every input value goes to exactly one output value. The answer is that relation a is a function, but relation b is not.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Is the Relation a Function?

A relation is a set of ordered pairs. The set of the first components of each ordered pair are the inputs and the set of the second components of each ordered pair are the outputs. Consider the following set of ordered pairs. The first numbers in each pair are the first five natural numbers. The second number in each pair is twice that of the first.

{\((1,2),(2,4),(3,6),(4,8),(5,10)\)}

The set of inputs is {\(1,2,3,4,5\)}. The set of outputs is {\(2,4,6,8,10\)}.

Each input value is the independent variable, and is often labeled with the lowercase letter x. Each output value, is the dependent variable dependent variable, and is often labeled lowercase letter y.

A function f is a relation that assigns a single output to each input. In other words, no x-values are repeated. For our example that relates the first five natural numbers to numbers double their values, this relation is a function because each input, {1,2,3,4,5}, is paired with exactly one output, {\(2,4,6,8,10\)}.

Now let’s consider the set of ordered pairs that relates the terms “even” and “odd” to the first five natural numbers. It would appear as

{ (odd,1),(even,2),(odd,3),(even,4),(odd,5) }

Notice that each input, {even,odd} is not paired with exactly one output, {\(1,2,3,4,5\)}. For example, the term “odd” corresponds to three output values, {1,3,5} and the term “even” corresponds to two output values, {\(2,4\)}. This violates the definition of a function, so this relation is not a function.

A mapping is sometimes used to show a relation. The arrows show the pairing of the inputs with the outputs.

Here are some relations that are functions and not functions.

  1. This relationship is a function because each input is associated with a single output. Note that inputs \(q\) and \(r\) both give output \(n\).
  2. This relationship is also a function. In this case, each input is associated with a single output.
  3. This relationship is not a function because input \(q\) is associated with two different outputs.

Given a relationship between two quantities, determine whether the relationship is a function.

  1. Identify the input values.
  2. Identify the output values.
  3. If each input value leads to only one output value, classify the relationship as a function. If any input value leads to two or more outputs, do not classify the relationship as a function.

Try It: Is the Relation a Function?

Is the following relation a function? Explain your answer.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to determine if this relation is a function:

Since every input (name) goes to only one output (birthday), this relation is a function.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.1.4: Describing Functional Relationships
page.contents:
Activity

In a function, there are two quantities called variables. The independent variable is the input, while the dependent variable is the output.

Here are two pairs of quantities from a situation you’ve seen in this lesson. Each pair has a relationship that can be defined as a function.

  • Time, in seconds, since the dog owner left and the total number of times the dog has barked
  • Time, in seconds, since the owner left and the total distance, in feet, that the dog has walked while waiting

Choose one pair of quantities and express their relationship as a function.

  1. In that function, which variable is independent? Which one is dependent?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The time, in seconds, since the owner left is independent. The total number of times the dog has barked is dependent.

The time, in seconds, since the owner left is independent. The total distance, in feet, the dog walked while waiting is dependent.


  1. Write a sentence of the form “____ is a function of ____.”

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

The total number of times the dog has barked is a function of the time, in seconds, since the owner left.

The total distance, in feet, is a function of the time, in seconds, since the owner left.




  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Sketch a possible graph of the relationship on the coordinate plane. Be sure to label and indicate a scale on each axis, and be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:


Video: Determining Independent and Dependent Variables

Watch the following video to learn more about independent and dependent variables.

answer.answer_text: Previous
Next

page.title: 4.1.4: Self Check
page.contents: The number of unread emails in Bryan’s account is 100. This number grows by 15 unread emails a day. Which of the following is true about this relationship?

answer.answer_text: Time, in days, is a function of the number of emails.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The input is time, and the output is the number of emails in the account. The answer is that the number of emails is a function of time in days.

answer.answer_text: The number of emails is a function of time in days.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The input is time, and the output is the number of emails in the account.

answer.answer_text: There is not a functional relationship between time and the number of emails.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: There is exactly one output, number of emails, for each input, time in days. The answer is that the number of emails is a function of time in days.

answer.answer_text: The number of unread emails is a function of the number of new unread emails.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The input is time, and the output is the number of emails in the account. The answer is that the number of emails is a function of time in days.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.1.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Identifying if a Relationship Is a Function

A function is a relation in which each possible input value leads to exactly one output value. We say “the output is a function of the input.”

Given a relationship between two quantities, determine whether the relationship is a function.

  1. Identify the input values.
  2. Identify the output values.
  3. If each input value leads to only one output value, classify the relationship as a function. If any input value leads to two or more outputs, do not classify the relationship as a function.

Example 1:

The coffee shop menu, shown below, consists of items and their prices.


  1. Is price a function of the item?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Let’s begin by considering the input values as the items on the menu. The output values are then the prices. Each item on the menu has only one price, so the price is a function of the item.



  1. Is the item a function of the price?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Two items on the menu have the same price. If we consider the prices to be the input values and the items to be the output, then the same input value could have more than one output associated with it. See the image below. Therefore, the item is a not a function of price.


Example 2:

Determining if Class Grade Rules Are Functions

In a particular math class, the overall percent grade corresponds to a grade point average. Is grade point average a function of the percent grade? Is the percent grade a function of the grade point average? Table 1 shows a possible rule for assigning grade points.

Percent grade

0–56

57–61

62–66

67–71

72–77

78–86

87–91

92–100

Grade point average

0.0

1.0

1.5

2.0

2.5

3.0

3.5

4.0

Solution

For any percent grade earned, there is an associated grade point average, so the grade point average is a function of the percent grade. In other words, if we input the percent grade, the output is a specific grade point average.

In the grading system given, there is a range of percent grades that correspond to the same grade point average. For example, students who receive a grade point average of 3.0 could have a variety of percent grades, ranging from 78 all the way to 86. Thus, percent grade is not a function of grade point average.

Try It: Identifying if a Relationship Is a Function

The table below lists the five greatest baseball players of all time in order of rank.


Player

Rank

Babe Ruth

1

Willie Mays

2

Ty Cobb

3

Walter Johnson

4

Hank Aaron

5


  1. Is the rank a function of the player name?
  2. Is the player name a function of the rank?

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to determine which variable is a function of the other:

Identify the input and output.

  1. Since the name is the input and the rank is the output, the rank is a function of the player name.
  2. Since the rank is the input and the name is the output, the player name is a function of the rank.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.1.5: Modeling Relationships between Two Variables
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A parent is using a garden hose to fill up a small inflatable pool for her young child. The pool has a capacity of 90 gallons. She turns the water off after 5 minutes, but she leaves the hose in the pool for another 3 minutes before putting it away.

In this situation, the relationship between the gallons of water in the pool and the time, in minutes, since the parent started filling the pool can be seen as a function.

  1. In that function, which variable is independent? Which one is dependent?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The time is independent. The amount of water is dependent.



  1. Write a sentence of the form “____ is a function of ____.” 

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The amount of water, in gallons, is a function of time, in minutes, since water started filling the pool.





  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Sketch a possible graph of the relationship on the coordinate plane. Be sure to label and indicate a scale on each axis.

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

answer.answer_text: Previous
Next

page.title: 4.1.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The relationship between the amount of time a car is parked, in hours, and the cost of parking, in dollars, can be described with a function.
    1. Identify the independent variable and the dependent variable in this function.
      Independent Variable

Correct! The independent variable is the amount of time the car is parked.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.1.1–4.1.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the independent variable is the amount of time the car is parked. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Describe the function with a sentence of the form “_1__ is a function of _2__ .”
      1 _____

Correct! The cost of parking.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.1.1-4.1.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the cost of parking. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


    1. 2 _____

Correct! The amount of time the car is parked.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.1.1–4.1.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the amount of time the car is parked. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Suppose it costs $3 per hour to park, with a maximum cost of $12. Here is a graph of the situation:

      What does the point \((2,6)\) mean in this situation?

Correct! 2 hours of parking costs a total of $6.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.1.1–4.1.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2 hours of parking costs a total of $6. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The distance a person walks, \(d\), in kilometers, is a function of time, \(t\), in minutes, since the walk began.

    Select all the true statements about the input value of this function.

Correct! Time since the person started walking is the input; \(t\) represents the input.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.1.3–4.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: Time since the person started walking is the input; \(t\) represents the input. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the following relation a function?
    {\((27,−3),(8,−2),(1,−1),(0,0),(1,1),(8,2),(27,3)\)}

Correct! No. Since the input value 1 goes to both –1 and 1, this relation is not a function.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: No. Since the input value 1 goes to both –1 and 1, this relation is not a function. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the following relation a function? Explain your answer.

Correct! No, this relation is not a function. Since both George and Mike are mapped to two different phone numbers, every input does not have exactly one output value.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: No, this relation is not a function. Since both George and Mike are mapped to two different phone numbers, every input does not have exactly one output value. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the following relation a function? Explain your answer.
    {\((7,−3),(−5,−4),(8,−0),(0,0),(−6,4),(−2,2),(−1,3)\)}

Correct! This relation is a function. Every input has exactly one output value

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: This relation is a function. Every input has exactly one output value. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

answer.answer_text: Previous
Next

page.title: 4.1.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain when a relationship between two quantities is a function.
  • Identify independent and dependent variables in a function, and use words and graphs to represent the function.
  • Explain what descriptions and graphs of functions tell us about situations.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.1.1: Contrasting Two Relationships by Reasoning
    • In this activity, you looked at which relationships represent a function and learned which quantities are functions of the other.
  • 4.1.2: Reasoning Graphically About the Relationship between the Two Quantities
    • In this activity, you sketched graphs about a dog’s movement as distance was a function of time.
  • 4.1.2: Self Check
  • 4.1.3: Examining Relations and Functions
    • In this activity, you determined if relations are functions by looking at the given inputs and outputs.
  • 4.1.3: Self Check
  • 4.1.4: Describing Functional Relationships
    • In this activity, you identified the independent and dependent variables in functional relationships. You also determined which variable was a function of the other to make statements about the relationship.
  • 4.1.4: Self Check
  • 4.1.5: Modeling Relationships between Two Variables
    • In this activity, you summarized everything you have learned in this lesson by identifying independent and dependent variables of a situation, determining which variable is a function of the other, and sketching a graph of the situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.1.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

answer.answer_text: Previous
End of Lesson
